Other Notes: Second part is Greek translation of Palmyrene divine name Yarḥbôl

Translation: May Saul son of Barnai be remembered
Other Notes: Hebrew name; same individual in D 41, 67, 100
Malichos is common name in Palmyra
Painted in red on white plaster ground, the whole enclosed in a wreath on white an green
Variant of name Σαλαμανης, found frequently at Dura
Unclear what the final letters mean. If they form a date, then it is Seleucid era 130, or 183/2 BCE, which would make this by far the earliest dated inscription at Dura
Common name at Dura
Name found elsewhere at Dura

Translation: May ? son of Danumos be rememered

Inscription: μνησθῆι Mανέος Δυσ[ίου] / Ῥαθίνου καὶ Ὀωαγεινῶσ
Translation: May Maneos son of Lysios Rathinos and Ovageinos be remembered

Other Notes: This is a graffito cut in very large, crude letters on the plaster of the third-century frescoes over the doorway into the south tower.
Name found elsewhere at Dura

Inscription: μν(ησθῆι) Δομείτοσς Σαλμάνο[υ] που στατωρ τριβούνι
Translation: May Domitius son of Salamanes, stator to tribune be remembered
Other Notes: Inscription cut in a tabella ansata. Traces of red paint remain in the letters. It is unclear what "που" is doing. It is possible that it is a repetition of the date Γου᾽ found in D32, especially since the father's name there is also Salamanes

Translation: May Taimarsou son of Niaxos, beneficiarius to the tribune, be remembered
Other Notes: Inscription cut in a tabella ansata. Traces of red paint remain in the letters.

Translation: May Mokimos Ogas, stator to the tribune, be rememberd
Other Notes: Inscription cut in a tabella ansata. Ogas is a Palmyrene name.

Translation: The name Μίδων is suggested for this.

Inscription: μν(ησθῆι) Ἑτερ/έος στ/άτω τ/ριβούν/ι από Δομ[άνας]
Translation: Hetereius stator to the tribune from Domana
Other Notes: There are two towns named Domana, one in Armenia (Ptol. V, vii, 3) and one in Arabia Felix (Ptol. VI, vii, 33)

Translation: May Theodotos, beneficiarius to the tribune, be remembered
Other Notes: Inscription represented in fig. 8 p. 121.

Translation: Nabumalik son of Salamis 476 SE of the Caesariani
Other Notes: The date 476 of the Seleucid Era is 164/5 CE, the date of Lucius Verus' march down the Euphrates and seizure of Dura-Europos. This date is met elsewhere on the Palmyrene Gate: in R. 18, an inscription by the same individual, R. 17 and D. 103.
The date 344 of the Seleucid Era is 32/3 CE.

Translation: Malxos son of ?, stator, be remembered.

Inscription: μν(ησθῆι) 'Addaῖο[ς] καὶ Ἠρεκλείδη[ς] Ῥονναίο[υ τοῦ] Μείδωνο[ς]
Translation: May Addaios and Herakleides sons of Ronnaios, son of Meidon be remembered
Other Notes: It is possible to restore this inscription also as the three sons of Meidon: μν(ησθῆι) 'Addaῖ[ς] Ἠρεκλείδη[ς] Ῥονναίος Μείδωνο[ς]

Translation: May Obê son of Theozandaas be remembered
Other Notes: Ὀβαῖος is Palmyrene name Obê.

Inscription: μνησθῆι Βω.ος / Ευχᾶριστῶ τῆι τύχης / Δούραν / Νηφαρακ Τέλος πώρτας Βαρνέος Βαρβαρνεος [εος] τέλος
Translation: May Boos be rememberded by favorable Fortune; Nefarak [is in the] office of [mantaining the] gates at Dura; Barneos Sele; Saul Barbarnaios [is in the] office [of maintaining] the gates [at] Dura
Other Notes: Inscription

Translation: Whoever makes obeisance to fortune of Dura...
Other Notes: It is very unfortunate that the condition of the stone prevents the reading of any but scattered letters after this, as it is certain that the older custom encountered by Apollonius at Babylon, of inisting that travelers salute a god of the city or the image of the king as evidence of good faith, was continued by the Roamns and applied to the Fortune

Translation: Marrous, son of Zedaios, son of Marrous

Other Notes: This name is well known at Dura.

Translation: The Europian Apollonios son of Apollonios
Other Notes: Together with the two texts in the Tower of the Palmyrene Gods, (H. 46 and H. 47), this is the first epigraphical apperances of the Greek name of the city, Europos
The second iota is the stroke originally intended for kappa, but cut too close to a crack
A later inscription has been superimposed on an earlier one
Semitic name common at Dura
Doubtful reconstruction
Abid- is so common an element of Semitic names that it is impossible to restore here.

Translation: May Malikos N...oneous be remembered, in the year 491or 494 SE

Other Notes: Both names are common at Palmyra; this is the first apperance of Soraichos at Dura
No further letters seem to have been inscribed
See discussion p. 156 for meaning of two words
Very small, faint letters.

Translation: Heliodoros (?) son of Theophilos son of Lysias, tax collector
Other Notes: Heliodoros would fir the space satisfactorily, but there are other possible resotrations.
Large shallow letters; the stone is badlu damaged by weather and the heat from the altar beneath it. The same individual appears in D. 43.

The date 296 of the Seleucid Era is 17/16 BCE. The position of this inscription with relaiton to the altar underneath it (on which is inscription D.74) shows that the altar is earlier. Doubt had been cast on the date ΡΟΘ (170 SE) on this altar because of its apparent lateness of style.
The year 170 of the Seleucid Era is 134/133 BCE. The order of the numbers, unusual at Dura, is common enough on papyri and other Hellenistic documents.
Very shallow letters, painted black
The red paint of these letters is well preserved. Professors Torrey and Albright agree that this name is Aramic Barkalba, lit "son of Kalba" ("the dog")

Translation: Ammonios son of Apollonios son of Athenodoros 390 SE
Other Notes: The date 390 of the Seleucid Era is 78/9 CE/
Macedonian interchange of episoln and alpha
Nabataean
The Semitic root ṣ r m has teh meaning 'bold, audacious.' The abstract noun serimū(tha) means 'boldness.' This suggests that our name was Serīm-zakhē, the '(the) bold conquers.
The name Nikanor, echoing the traditional founder of the city, has already been found by Cumont.

Translation: Artemidoros son of Gondazos and Olympos Nikanor
Other Notes: Alternative reading of Γονδάζου is Γονδάξου
Kallistratos is an alternative restoration

Translation: Theodoros son of Lišamš son of Asmaos
Other Notes: The name Lišamš is the excessivly common Palmyrene (Arabic) Λίσαμος, found also in H. 8. The third name my also be read Ἀσάδου. If this be corrected to Ἀσάδου, it is the common Arabaic 'Asad, "Lion," often found in transcription as Ἄσαδος
Unquestionably equivalent to the Armaic (Palmyrene) Šemiš ´aqab.
The reading is not certain.
Graffito. Name also appers in D.11.

Inscription: Σηλαιος / τελώνης / Σιλαῖος Βαρνά/οσι (sic) / Νηφαρακ / λβρσ [Ση] λαῖο[ς]
Translation: Saul tax collector, Silaios for Bar Nāšā,  Nēfarrak, belong to Bar Nāšā, Saul
Other Notes: For the letters λβρσ Professor Gray suggests an abbreviation, the Greeks letters, of Syriac l(e)B(a)r(Nā)š(ā) "for (or of, belonging to) Bar Nāšā
Very large, vague letters

Translation: Gatekeepers Addaios son of Akollaios, Akkollaios son of Addaios

Inscription: Γου´/ Γωσαῖος Νααστά/βου πυλουρὸς καὶ βουκόλος Ναάσταβος Γω/σαί[υ]
Translation: 476 SE the gatekeeper Gosaios son of Naastabos, and herdsman Naastabos son of Gosaios
Other Notes: The date 476 of the Seleucid Era is 164/5 CE. Other inscriptiosn of the same date are R. 17 and R. 19 and D. 34.
This name also appears in D. 39.
Graffito
This reading is extremely doubtful.
Large, shallow letters.
Across the top of this is a Safaitic inscription.
Large, shallow letters.
Large, shallow letters.

Translation: Diodotos son of Lysias son of Alexander
Herodotus son of Barlaos son of ?

Other Notes: The reading is very doubtful.

Source: West Wall of North Tower, facing the desert
Other Notes: Palmyrene name

Source: East Wall of North Tower, facing the city
Other Notes: This was in later times convered by plaster steps.

Source: Right jamb of the doorway into the south tower
Left wall of passage of the doorway into the south tower

Other Notes: Arabic name meaning Servant of the Goddess Lât (Allât)

Inscription: Μνησθείης Αδαδ[ακ]α[βος] / καὶ Βαρ [. . .]ν Ζαβαδν[άνου] / πρὸς τοὺς θεοὺς καὶ Άρ[τέμιδα ?] / [. .]ω τοὺς καὶ Ὀφ[- -] χ[- -]
Translation: May Adad-acab and Zadab-Nani be remembered for the gods and Ar(temides?) ...
Other Notes: Aramaic names in otherwise fragmentary inscription
On some fragments of plasater still adhering to this stone are a few letters, 1 cm. high: εψι / παρ
